{{coi|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox school |name = Preshil
The Margaret Lyttle Memorial School |image = |motto = Courage |established = 1931{{cite web|url = http://www.schoolchoice.com.au/schools_vic/find_a_school?cid=12222&pid=1865853|title = Preshil The Margaret Lyttle Memorial School|accessdate = 2007-10-09|year = 2007|work = Victoria|publisher = School Choice}} |type = [[Independent school|Independent]], [[Co-educational]], [[Progressivism|Progressive school]], [[Day school]] |denomination = [[Secular]] |slogan = |principal = Marilyn Smith |founder = Margaret J. R. Lyttle |city = [[Kew, Victoria|Kew]] |state = [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] |country = Australia |coordinates = {{coord|37|48|48|S|145|2|58|E|region:AU-VIC_type:edu|display=inline,title}} |enrolment = ~350 (P–12) |staff = ~52{{cite web|url = http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/assets/downloads/2007-Preshil-Ann-Rep.pdf|title = Annual Report to Parents|accessdate = 2007-10-09|last = Millane|first = Vivien |year = 2007|format = PDF|work = About|publisher = Preshil School |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070830075528/http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/assets/downloads/2007-Preshil-Ann-Rep.pdf |archivedate = 2007-08-30}} |colours = Green and Gold {{color box|#008000}}{{color box|#FFD700}} |website = [http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/ www.preshil.vic.edu.au] }} '''Preshil, The Margaret Lyttle Memorial School''', is an [[Independent school|independent]], [[secular]], [[co-educational]], day school located in [[Kew, Victoria|Kew]], an eastern suburb of [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia. The original Arlington campus houses the Kindergarten and Primary school, while the Secondary School is located at the Blackhall Kalimna campus. Established in 1931 by Greta Lyttle (and later, Margaret Lyttle), Preshil teaches a [[Progressivism|progressive]] curriculum.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/education/where-children-rule-in-a-spirit-of-progress-20110807-1ihlq.html|title=Where children rule in a spirit of progress|last=Carey|first=Adam|date=2011-08-07|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}} Preshil is Australia’s oldest progressive school.{{Cite news|url=http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/our-school/history-of-preshil/|title=History of Preshil - Preshil|work=Preshil|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en-US}} Preshil teaches students from Kindergarten through to Year 12. The school phased out the [[Victorian Certificate of Education]] in 2017 in favour of the [[International Baccalaureate]] programme.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/education/school-set-to-axe-vce-because-it-is-too-competitive-20151031-gknv40.html|title=Preshil in Kew set to axe VCE because it is too competitive|last=Cook|first=Henrietta|date=2015-11-01|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-09-20|last2=reporter|first2=education|language=en-US}} ==Notable alumni== *[[Clare Bowditch]], musician, [[ARIA Music Awards of 2006|winner of Best Female Artist award at 2006 ARIAS]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} *[[Lauren Burns]], Olympic gold medallist, taekwondo, Sydney 2000.[http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/alumni/featured-alumni/], ''Featured Alumni'', accessed 18 July 2010. *[[Dash and Will]], Australian indie pop group *[[Nicolette Fraillon]], Chief Conductor of [[The Australian Ballet]] Orchestra[http://www.preshil.vic.edu.au/2014/05/principals-blog-august-20th-2010/] *[[Todd Goldstein]], Australian Football player for [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]] *[[Greg Hjorth]], mathematician and chess champion *[[Kaiya Jones]], Australian actress, known for The Saddle Club and Neighbours * [[Peter Singer]], philosopher * [[Gina Riley]], actor * [[Zahava Elenberg]], architect ==See also== *[[List of schools in Victoria]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *Burns, L. ''Fighting Spirit'' (Penguin Books, 2003). {{ISBN|0-670-04037-1}} *Lyttle, Dermot. ''Preshil Uniquely Different'' (Kew: Preshil, 2002). *White, Naomi Rosh. ''School Matters: The Preshil Alternative in Education'' (Port Melbourne: Mandarin, 1995). ==External links== * [http://www.heraldsun.news.com.au/common/story_page/0,5478,17394511%255E5000114,00.html "Preshil vision is still splendid"] by Matthew Pinkney, ''Herald Sun'', 29 November 2005. *[http://www.abc.net.au/rn/hindsight/stories/2006/1674657.htm Preshil and progressive education in Australia] ABC Radio National {{Alternative education}} [[Category:Private schools in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Schools in Melbourne]] [[Category:Alternative schools]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1931]] [[Category:1931 establishments in Australia]] {{VictoriaAU-school-stub}}

'''Rhetaugh Etheldra Graves Dumas''' (1928–2007) was an American nurse, professor, and health administrator. Dumas was the first Black woman to serve as a dean at the [[University of Michigan]]. She served as deputy director of the [[National Institute of Mental Health]], becoming the first nurse, female, or African-American to hold that position.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lib.umich.edu/faculty-history/faculty/rhetaugh-graves-dumas/memoir|title=Memoir {{!}} Faculty History Project|website=www.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> She is said to have been the first nurse to use the scientific method to conduct experiments that evaluated nursing practices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cpnas.org/aahp/biographies/rhetaugh-graves-dumas.html|title=Rhetaugh Graves Dumas|website=www.cpnas.org|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
Dumas died on July 22 2007 of ovarian cancer.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Barron McBride|first=Angela|date=Fall 2007|title=Remembering Rhetaugh Graves Dumas, PhD, RN, FAAN|url=https://www.nursingoutlook.org/article/S0029-6554(07)00187-X/abstract|journal=Nursing Outlook|volume=55|pages=264|via=}}</ref>
==Early Life and Education== Rhetaugh Etheldra Graves was born in [[Natchez, Mississippi]]. Dumas' mother had wanted to become a nurse, but no local nursing schools admitted African-American students at the time and her family could not afford to send her to college further away.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/27/AR2007072700332.html|title=Rhetaugh Dumas, 78; Nurse Rose To Become NIMH Deputy Director|last=Sullivan|first=Patricia|date=2007-07-27|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
When Dumas spoke at the Columbia University 2003 commencement for health sciences graduates, she said "From infancy, I was told that when I grew up, I was going to be a nurse, not just an ordinary nurse, mind you, but one who would be admired by people all around the country -- not only for her personal achievements, but more importantly, for her contributions toward improving the welfare of others."<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
She obtained her nursing degree at Dillard University in New Orleans in 1951.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lib.umich.edu/faculty-history/faculty/rhetaugh-graves-dumas/memoir|title=Memoir {{!}} Faculty History Project|website=www.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> Following graduation, she took her first jobs as a substitute teacher in Natchez<ref name=":1" /> and as the Nurse Director of Dillard University’s Student Health Center.<ref name=":0" />
Dumas died of cancer in a Houston hospice on July 22, 2007.<ref name="Post">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/27/AR2007072700332.html|title=Rhetaugh Dumas, 78; Nurse Rose To Become NIMH Deputy Director|last=Sullivan|first=Patricia|date=July 27, 2007|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref>
==Work== Dumas earned a master's degree in nursing in 1961 from [[Yale University]] and joined the school's faculty, ultimately becoming an associate professor and the chair of psychiatric nursing.<ref name=Post/> While at Yale, she served as a member of the Board of Public School Education in [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]] and helped mental health professionals get involved with parents and students during the school riots of the 1960s.<ref name=":0" /> She worked simultaneously as Director of Nursing at the Connecticut Mental Health Center and as Chair of the Yale Department of Psychiatric Nursing.<ref name=":0" />
Beginning in the 1970s, Dumas held leadership positions with the [[National Institute of Mental Health]]. She was the chief of the organization's Psychiatric Nursing Education Branch.<ref name="Award" /> Between 1979 and 1981, she was the first nurse, female, or African-American to serve as the deputy director of the NIMH.<ref name="Post" /><ref name="Award" /> In 1979 she was appointed by Patricia Roberts Harris, secretary of Health and Human Services, to the position of deputy director.<ref name=":1" /> During her time at the NIMH, according to her obituary in Nursing Outlook, she "played a major role in redirecting professional training to meet the needs of the unserved and underserved, a policy focus that continues to this day."<ref name=":0" /> While at NIMH, Dumas earned a doctoral degree from [[Union Institute & University|Union Institute]].<ref name="Post" />
Dumas worked for the University of Michigan for over 20 years, and she served three terms there as the nursing school dean. Dumas was the first Black female dean at Michigan, but left the position when she was appointed Vice Provost for Health and the Lucille Cole Professor of Nursing.<ref name="Award" />
Dumas served terms as president of the [[American Academy of Nursing]] and the [[National League for Nursing]]. She was a member of the [[Institute of Medicine]] and a fellow of the A.K. Rice Institute. She received a presidential appointment to the National Bioethics Advisory Committee and she was awarded the President's 21st Century Award from the National Women's Hall of Fame. She was a Charter Fellow of the American Academy of Nursing and was named a Living Legend by the academy in 2002.<ref name="NAS">{{cite web|title=African-American History Program: Rhetaugh Graves Dumas|url=http://www.cpnas.org/aahp/biographies/rhetaugh-graves-dumas.html|publisher=[[National Academy of Sciences]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref><ref name="AAN">{{cite web|title=Living Legends|url=http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list|publisher=[[American Academy of Nursing]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412055058/http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list|archivedate=April 12, 2012|df=}}</ref> Dumas received honorary doctorates from the [[University of Cincinnati]], [[University of San Diego]], [[Yale University]] and [[Dillard University]].<ref name="Record">{{cite news|title=Obituaries|url=http://www.ur.umich.edu/0607/Aug13_07/obits.shtml|accessdate=May 20, 2013|newspaper=The University Record|date=August 13, 2007}}</ref> She gave the keynote address at the 1998 conference of the American Association for the History of Nursing in Mississippi.<ref name="AAHN">{{cite web|title=AAHN Past Conferences|url=http://www.aahn.org/pastconf.html|publisher=American Association for the History of Nursing|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref>
Her published work includes "The Effect of Nursing Care on Postoperative Vomiting"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/27/AR2007072700332.html|title=Rhetaugh Dumas, 78; Nurse Rose To Become NIMH Deputy Director|last=Sullivan|first=Patricia|date=2007-07-27|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> and "Dilemmas of Black Females in Leadership."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=Gwendolyn|date=June 1984|title=The Black WomanTHE BLACK WOMAN. Edited by Rodgers-RoseLa Frances. Beverly Hills, CA: Sage Publications, Inc., 1980.|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/036168438400800401|journal=Psychology of Women Quarterly|volume=8|issue=4|pages=400–403|doi=10.1177/036168438400800401|issn=0361-6843}}</ref>
==Legacy== The University of Michigan Academic Women's Caucus issues the Rhetaugh G. Dumas Progress in Diversifying Award for "notable progress by academic units in achieving concurrent ethnic/racial and gender diversity in the faculty."<ref name=Award>{{cite web|title=Rhetaugh G. Dumas Award|url=http://sitemaker.umich.edu/awc/nomination_form_2013_rhetaugh_dumas__award|publisher=[[University of Michigan]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref> Michigan and Yale have both established endowed chairs in their nursing schools in her name.<ref name=":1" />
==See also== *[[List of Living Legends of the American Academy of Nursing]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dumas, Rhetaugh Etheldra Graves}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American nursing administrators]] [[Category:Dillard University alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Union Institute & University alumni]] [[Category:University of Michigan faculty]] [[Category:Yale University faculty]] [[Category:Living Legends of the American Academy of Nursing]] [[Category:Nursing school deans]] [[Category:Nursing educators]] [[Category:American academic administrators]] [[Category:Women academic administrators]] [[Category:20th-century American women]]

{{Refimprove|date=October 2008}} {{Infobox school | name = Saint Mary's Academy | motto = ''Ora Et Labora'' | motto_translation = Pray and Work | established = 1932 | type = [[Private School|Private]] [[Catholic School]] | principal = Brother James (acting principal) | staff = approximately 30 (2008) | country = [[Dominica]] | city = [[Roseau]] | website = http://www.da-academy.org/sma.html }}
'''Saint Mary's Academy - Dominica''' (abbreviated as '''SMA''') is an all-boy [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[Educational stages#England and Wales|secondary]] school in [[Roseau, Dominica|Roseau]], [[Dominica]]. SMA offers [[Educational stages#England and Wales|First Form]] through [[Educational stages#England and Wales|Fifth Form]], which is generally followed by two years of non-compulsory further education – often at a [[Sixth Form College]].
==History==
The founder of the school is [[Edmund Ignatius Rice|Blessed Edmund Rice]]. Blessed Edmund Rice was given the Grace to respond to the call of Jesus by identifying with Christ in the poor. His example evoked a deep awareness of God's loving presence in all with whom he came in contact. He awakened within them consciousness of their dignity as children of God. He invited his followers to share his Gospel insight, and empowered them to reach out to the needy, especially the materially poor. The life of blessed Edmund Rice - businessman, husband, father, widower, religious brother, teacher and founder - challenges all involved in Christian Brother Education to live and teach Gospel values in today's world. His charisma inspired the essential elements of a Christian Brother Education.
==Mission statement==
(For the St. Mary's Academy and all other Catholic Schools in [[Dominica]]).
{{cquote|1.To give priority to education in a living faith whereby students grow to appreciate the life and mission of Jesus Christ with a view to being committed to the world as he was. 2.To have special concern for the poor and the under-privileged.
3.To develop a curriculum which promotes the harmonious development of the whole person.
The Catholic School, S.M.A, works at forming a community composed of students, teachers, parents, management and other staff. This community:
*seeks to live by the Gospel values. *recognizes the dignity of each individual. *contributes to the building up of the local community. *works for peace and justice in society.|cquote}}
==Uniform==
The Academy's uniform consists of a white shirt jack with the school's crest pinned to the breast pocket however the student desires. Brown khaki pants are worn, except for special occasions, like church masses, where black pants are worn.
==Student Council==
At the beginning of every school year that commences in September, [[student council]]s are chosen by the pupils. The party normally consists of a President, a Vice-President, a public relations officer ([[chief communications officer]]), [[treasurer]], and a [[secretary]].
==Buildings== The S.M.A. compound consists of two main buildings, the Old Wing, and the New Wing (Brother Germain Wing). The Principal's office is located on the bottom floor of the Old Wing, and there are two staff rooms, one on the Old Wing, and another on the New Wing.
The Old Wing has only two floors. It is the main building of the school. On the bottom floor is the principal's office, the room's 101 to 105 and an old lab which is used for building technology. On the top floor is the staff room, then rooms 201 to 206. (All rooms respective from right to left.)
The New Wing is the latest addition to the compound. It was built in 1998, and was named after a past principal, Bro. Germain. The New Wing has three floors. The bottom floor has a library, the councilor's office, and a science lab. On the second floor is the lowest level class-room, WA5. Next, the New Staff-Room, then the computer lab. On the third floor is WA1, WA2, WA3, and WA4. (All rooms are respective from left to right.)
[[Category:Educational institutions established in 1932]] [[Category:Education in Dominica]]
{{Caribbean-school-stub}}

{{advert|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox University |name =Sessions College for Professional Design |native_name = |latin_name = |image =Sessions college professional design logo.png |motto =The highest quality in online arts education |established =1997 |type =Private |endowment = |staff = |faculty = |president =Gordon Drummond |principal = |rector = |chancellor = |vice_chancellor = |dean = |head_label = |head = |students =1,500 |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |city ={{flagicon|USA}}[[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]] |state =[[Arizona]] |country =[[United States]] |campus =Electronic |free_label = |free = |colors =Blue, green, and orange {{Color box|#0067b1|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#66b360|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#f99d31|border=darkgray}} |colours = |mascot = |nickname =Sessions |former_names =Sessions.edu
Sessions Online Schools of Art and Design |affiliations = |website =[http://www.sessions.edu/] }} {{coord|33.426669|N|111.940271|W|type:edu|display=title}}'''Sessions College for Professional Design''' is a fully accredited [[online college]] offering career training programs for both aspiring and established creative and design professionals. Sessions offers vocational certificates, undergraduate certificates and associate degrees in a variety of art and design fields. The main campus of Sessions College is located in [[Tempe, Arizona]] on historic Mill Avenue. Courses are delivered entirely [[online]]. Sessions College has graduated students from over 80 countries worldwide. ==History== Sessions College was founded in 1997, originally located and licensed in [[New York state]]; in 2009, Sessions moved its campus to [[Tempe, Arizona]] and secured licensure from the Arizona State Board for Private Postsecondary Education.[http://azppse.state.az.us/directory/ Arizona State Board for Private Postsecondary Education Directory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807223636/http://azppse.state.az.us/directory/ |date=2010-08-07 }} ==Accreditation and Licensure== ===Accreditation=== The school has been accredited by the [[Distance Education and Training Council]] [http://www.detc.org/school_details.php?id=287 DETC - Sessions College Accredited Institution Listing] since 2001. Additionally, Sessions College certificate programs have been accredited by the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]] Commission on Secondary Schools [http://www.msa-cess.org/default.aspx?RelId=606553 CSS MSA listing for Sessions Online Schools of Art and Design] since 2006. ===State Licensure=== Sessions is licensed by the Arizona State Board for Private Postsecondary Education.[http://azppse.state.az.us/directory/ Arizona State Board for Private Postsecondary Education Directory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807223636/http://azppse.state.az.us/directory/ |date=2010-08-07 }} ===Other Authorizations and Memberships=== Sessions is: * Approved by the U.S. Department of Education to administer Federal Student Aid to eligible students. * A member of the [[USDLA|United States Distance Learning Association]] (USDLA)[http://www.usdla.org/html/membership/organizMembers.htm USDLA Organizational Members] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020718173456/http://www.usdla.org/html/membership/organizMembers.htm |date=2002-07-18 }} * A [[Workforce Investment Board]] (WIB) provider in the state of Arizona through the Arizona HEAT program.[http://www.ade.state.az.us/arizonaHEAT/providers/provider_information.asp?ID=943&returnP=1 Arizona HEAT listing for Sessions College] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627063306/http://www.ade.state.az.us/arizonaheat/providers/provider_information.asp?ID=943&returnP=1 |date=2010-06-27 }} ==Awards and Notable Achievements== In March 2014, ''GD USA Magazine'' named Sessions College among the top design schools in the United States,{{cite web |url=http://archive.gdusa.com/issue_2014/march/schools/index.php?s=19 |title=Highest Honors: Top Design Schools |publisher=GDUSA |accessdate=2017-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208205038/http://archive.gdusa.com/issue_2014/march/schools/index.php?s=19 |archivedate=2015-12-08 |df= }} in a list that included such respected traditional design schools as the [[School of Visual Arts]], [[RISD]], [[Maryland Institute College of Art]], [[California College of the Arts]], [[Parsons School of Design]], and [[Pratt Institute]], in addition to schools offering online programs such as [[Savannah College of Art and Design]], [[Academy of Art University]], and [[Full Sail University]]. In June 2014, BestColleges.com rated Sessions College among its top 100 online schools for 2014, and in the top 50 colleges offering online associate degree programs. The survey was compiled through the use of "student surveys, faculty surveys, independent research, ranking systems, and the input of highly credible and authoritative sources." In Summer 2014, Sessions College was nominated for a Best Value School Award by the Best Value Colleges organization. The Best Value School Award aims to provide an alternative to established metrics-based lists by highlighting small to medium-sized colleges and schools that offer not only an outstanding education but also value for money. The USDLA [[USDLA|United States Distance Learning Association]] (USDLA) has three times awarded Sessions College United States Distance learning Association awards for its contribution to distance education. In April 2012, Sessions College instructor Piper Nilsson won a USDLA Platinum award for teaching excellence - the highest honor bestowed by USDLA for teaching. In 2008, the Sessions College Graphic Design Certificate program received the USDLA Best Practices Award for Distance Learning Programming.[http://www.usdla.org/index.php?cid=118 USDLA 2008 awards page] Judges commended the program's creative and technical curriculum, one-to-one student mentoring, and dedicated faculty. In 2009, Sessions College received a second Gold Award for its Louis H. Schilt Memorial Scholarship for severely injured veterans.[http://www.usdla.org/index.php?cid=182 USDLA 2009 awards page] Sessions College has twice won ANGEL Impact Awards for online educational technology. The school received awards for its development of the My Gallery and Success Tracker tools, two customized extensions of the ANGEL LMS functionality. The purpose of the ANGEL awards was to recognize efforts to impact education, exemplary ANGEL implementation, and fostering innovation and collaboration. Sessions was an [[Inc. (magazine)#Inc.5000|Inc. 5000]] honoree in 2008[http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/company-profile.html?id=200839330 Inc. 5000 profile for Sessions, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108040629/http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/company-profile.html?id=200839330 |date=2009-01-08 }} and was ranked #40 in the Inc. 5000 2008 Top 50 Education Companies.[http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/lists/education-companies.html?o=0&c=200839330 Inc. Top 50 Education Companies, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013235537/http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/lists/education-companies.html?o=0&c=200839330 |date=2012-10-13 }} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.sessions.edu/ Sessions College Website] {{Colleges and Universities in Arizona|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sessions College For Professional Design}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1997]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Arizona]] [[Category:Distance education institutions]] [[Category:Online schools]] [[Category:Distance education institutions based in the United States]] [[Category:Distance Education Accreditation Commission]] [[Category:Online colleges]] [[Category:Graphic design schools]] [[Category:Online education]]

revision.text:
{{Globalize/US|date=March 2018}}
'''Sexism in academia''' refers to the [[discrimination]] and [[hierarchy|subordination]] of a particular sex in academic institutions, particularly [[university|universities]], due to the ideologies, practices and reinforcements that privilege one sex over another. Sexism in academia is not limited to but primarily affects women who are denied the professional achievements awarded to men in their respective fields such as positions, tenure and awards.<ref name=":02" Sexism in academia encompasses institutionalized and cultural sexist ideologies; it is not limited to the admission process and the under-representation of women in the sciences but also includes the denial of [[tenure]], positions and awards that are generally accorded to men.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Savigny|first=Heather|year=2014|title=Women, know your limits: cultural sexism in academia|url=https://search-ebscohost-com.echo.louisville.edu/login.aspx?direct=true&db=eric&AN=EJ1046728&site=ehost-live|journal=Gender & Education|volume=26|pages=|via=EBSCO}}</ref>
== Positions == There is controversy over whether women's under-representation in specific academic fields is the result of [[gender discrimination]] or of other factors such as personal inclination.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bird|first=Sharon|date=March 2011|title=Unsettling Universities' Incongruous, Gendered Bureaucratic Structures: A Case-study Approach|journal=Gender, Work & Organization|volume=18|issue=2|pages=202–230|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0432.2009.00510.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The blank slate : the denial of human nature in modern intellectual life|last1=Pinker|first1=Steven|date=2002|publisher=Viking|isbn=978-0-670-03151-1|edition=|location=New York|pages=ch 18|ref=blankslate}}</ref> Some individuals have argued that there are equal opportunities for women and men in sciences and that sexism no longer exists in these fields.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110207/full/470153a.html|title=Science gender gap probed|journal=Nature|volume=470|issue=7333|pages=153|last=Dickey|first=Z|access-date=|doi=10.1038/470153a|pmid=21307907|year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/news/equal-prospects-for-both-sexes-in-science-1.10053|title=Equal prospects for both sexes in science|journal=Nature|last=Gilbert|first=N|access-date=|doi=10.1038/nature.2012.10053|year=2012}}</ref> Researchers note that as of 2015, women had closed the undergraduate degree gap for several STEM fields including both the social and biological sciences, but women only accounted for approximately 20% of the computer science and engineering undergraduate degree holders. Likewise, at the master's and doctoral level, the number of STEM degrees obtained by women had increased for many fields; however, only 27% of the master's degrees and 23% of the doctoral degrees in computer science and engineering were held by women.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://research.swe.org/2016/08/degree-attainment/|title=Degree Attainment - Research and Trends for Women in STEM|date=2016-08-17|work=Research and Trends for Women in STEM|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref> These claims of equal opportunity in scientific fields of academia are often attributed to women's "preference" and inclination for other fields of study and to teaching instead of research. However, such claims do not take into account that gender is central to the organization of [[higher education]].<ref name=":12" /> This might explain women's under-representation in academia at more senior levels, and the way in which the organization of higher education institutions might be structurally disadvantaging women by the institutionalization, practice, and valuing of masculinity which ends up reinforcing hegemonic masculinities.<ref name=":02" /><ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wolffensberger|first=J|year=1993|title=Science is truly a male world: The interconnectedness of knowledge, gender and power within university education|journal=Gender and Education|volume=5|pages=37–54|doi=10.1080/0954025930050103}}</ref> Women are not represented in senior jobs in the humanities even though most students in these fields are women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=American Psychological Association|first=|year=2000|title=Women in academe: Two steps forward, one step back|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Tenure == Women are underrepresented in tenured positions. From 2001 to 2009, women averaged 35% of all full-time faculty with tenure and 43% of all full-time faculty in non-tenure track positions in comparison to men's 50% and 32%, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aaup.org/NR/rdonlyres/08E023AB-E6D8-4DBD-99A0-24E5EB73A760/0/persistent_inequity.pdf|title=Persistent Inequity: Gender and Academic Employment|last=Curtis|first=John|date=2011-04-11|website=American Association of University Professors|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-02}}</ref> A case study performed by the Pennsylvania State University in 2006 attributes a majority of this gap to familial commitments and the avoidance strategies they create among faculty members.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Drago|first=Robert|last2=Colbeck|first2=Carol L.|last3=Stauffer|first3=Kai Dawn|last4=Pirretti|first4=Amy|last5=Burkum|first5=Kurt|last6=Fazioli|first6=Jennifer|last7=Lazzaro|first7=Gabriela|last8=Habasevich|first8=Tara|date=2006-05|title=The Avoidance of Bias Against Caregiving|url=https://search-ebscohost-com.echo.louisville.edu/login.aspx?direct=true&db=eric&AN=EJ718750&site=ehost-live|journal=American Behavioral Scientist|volume=49|pages=1222-1247|issn=0002-7642|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> For instance, it takes approximately between five to seven years for a faculty member to be considered for the position of associate professor with tenure; this system limits caregiving and family responsibilities until tenure is achieved, so faculty members may choose to delay marriage, parenthood, etc. until the desired position is acquired.<ref name=":2" /> In particular, the careers of female academics are greatly hindered because the workplace tends to favor a male's career path. The travel, possibility of relocation and vigorous work schedules limit the participation of females due to family conflicts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fothergill|first=Alice|last2=Feltey|first2=Kathryn|date=|title="I've Worked Very Hard and Slept Very Little": Mothers on Tenure Track in Academia|url=|journal=Journal of the Association for Research on Mothering|volume=5|pages=|via=Google Scholar}}</ref> A 2006 national survey, reported 16% of female faculty remained single because they did not have time for both a family and a successful career; of the female faculty who were parents, 17.2% chose to have one child but delayed even considering another until they had acquired their desired position.<ref name=":2" /> These challenges associated with balancing work life and family life raise questions regarding the influence both marriage and motherhood have on the academic positions available to wives and mothers at colleges and universities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Perna|first=Laura W.|date=2001|title=The Relationship Between Family Responsibilities and Employment Status Among College and University Faculty|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/2672882.pdf?refreqid=excelsior%3A334b6e7913e8dc9d9f333e8489b729ed|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|volume=72|issue=5|pages=584-611|doi=10.2307/2672882|via=JSTOR}}</ref> Despite the increased support for family-friendly policies in the academic workplace, few have yet to be utilized fully. Many academies support paid parental leave, tenure-clock stoppage and flexible schedules; however, few faculty members of either sex choose to take advantage of these policies for fear of being penalized by their departments despite the institution's approval.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tKv1D26YYLEC&lpg=PR11&ots=P6NwRrrtiv&lr&pg=PA5#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Parenting and Professing: Balancing Family Work with an Academic Career|last=Bassett|first=Rachel Hile|date=2005|publisher=Vanderbilt University Press|year=|isbn=9780826514783|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Awards == Women are less likely to win academic awards. For instance, there are 48 women [[Nobel Prize]] winners, compared to 844 men.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/facts/|title=Nobel Prize Facts|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> About two-thirds of these winners won a Nobel Prize for a humanities discipline, not a science discipline.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/lists/women.html|title=Nobel Prize Awarded Women|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In most scientific disciplines, a small portion of women full professors are nominated for awards compared to the number of women in the field.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=27 January 2011|title=Scholar's awards mainly go to men|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/469472a|journal=Nature |volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The Recognition of the Achievements of Women In Science, Medicine, and Engineering (RAISE) project have reported that the women represent 8.6% of [[Lasker Award]] winners.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leboy|first=Phoebe|date=1 January 2008|title=Fixing the Leaky Pipeline|url=https://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/25887/title/Fixing-the-Leaky-Pipeline/|journal=The Scientist|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Women of color in academia == Women of color face specific issues related to sexism in academia as well. One such problem is referred to as the "Chilly Climate" problem, wherein, because women of color are infrequent in academia, they are often isolated and face a lack of institutional support.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ford|first=Kristie A.|date=2011|title=Race, Gender, and Bodily (Mis)Recognitions: Women of Color Faculty Experiences with White Students in the College Classroom|jstor=29789534|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|volume=82|issue=4|pages=444–478}}</ref> Additionally, because women of color's bodies are both viewed racially and in terms of their gender in academia, their voices and identities are often overlooked through "elite racism", as coined by Allen, Epps, Guillory, Suh, and Bonous-Hammarth (2000). Because women of color in academia are sometimes minorities in regards to their colleagues as well as their students, it is suggested that they feel the aforementioned isolation, racism, and sexism from both groups.
Women of color in academia are not only seemingly ostracized by their colleagues, but by their students as well. Women faculty of color reported having their authority questioned and challenged, their teaching competency questioned and their knowledge and experience disrespected by their students. White male students were also seen to behave more aggressively towards these women and would also employ intimidating behaviors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pittman|first=Chavella T.|date=2010|title=Race and Gender Oppression in the Classroom: The Experiences of Women Faculty of Color with White Male Students|jstor=27896528|journal=Teaching Sociology|volume=38|issue=3|pages=183–196}}</ref>
According to the National Science Foundation's 2015 survey of Doctorate recipients, only 40.41% of U.S. doctorate scientists employed in teaching positions were women, 61,750 out of a sample of 152,800. Of the female population, 75.95% were White, 11.01% were Asian, 5.34% were Hispanic or Latino, 5.67% were Black or African American, 0.32% were American Indian or Alaskan Native, and 1.62% constituted other races, including Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and those who marked multiple races who were not Hispanic or Latino. In addition, Asian women held 3% of tenured positions, Latinas 2.4%, and Black women 2.3% according to a 2015 survey by the National Center for Education Statistics.<ref>National Center for Education Statistics. (2016). Enrollment and employees in postsecondary institutions https://nces.ed.gov/pubs2017/2017024.pdf</ref>
==Women in academic publishing== In many academic disciplines, women receive less credit for their research than men.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | last1 = Ghiasi | first1 = Gita | last2 = Larivière | first2 = Vincent | last3 = Sugimoto | first3 = Cassidy R. | year = 2015 | title = On The Compliance Of Women Engineers With A Gendered Scientific System | url = | journal = PLOS ONE | volume = 10 | issue = 12| pages = 1–19 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0145931 | pmid = 26716831 | pmc = 4696668 }}</ref><ref name=":1">1. Sarsons, Heather. "Gender Differences in Recognition of Group Work". ''Harvard University.'' 2015. </ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jenkins | first1 = Fiona | year = 2014 | title = Epistemic Credibility And Women In Philosophy | url = | journal = Australian Feminist Studies | volume = 29 | issue = 80| pages = 161–170 | doi = 10.1080/08164649.2014.928190 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rigg | first1 = Lesley S. | last2 = McCarragher | first2 = Shannon | last3 = Krmenec | first3 = Andrew | year = 2012 | title = Authorship, Collaboration, And Gender: Fifteen Years Of Publication Productivity In Selected Geography Journals | url = | journal = Professional Geographer | volume = 64 | issue = 4| pages = 491–502 | doi = 10.1080/00330124.2011.611434 }}</ref> This trend is especially pronounced in engineering fields. A study published in 2015 by Gita Ghiasi, Vincent Lariviere, and Cassidy Sugimoto demonstrates that women represent 20% of all scientific production in the field of engineering. The study examined 679,338 engineering articles published between 2008 and 2013, and it analyzed the collaborative networks among 974,837 authors. Ghiasi et al. created networking diagrams, depicting the frequency of collaboration among authors, and the success of each collaboration was measured by the number of times the study was cited. The collaboration networks illustrate that mixed-gender teams have a higher average rate of productivity and citations, yet 50% of male engineers have collaborated only with other men and 38% of female engineers have collaborated only with men. The researchers use [[impact factor]]s—the average annual number of citation that a journal receives—to measure the prestige of academic journals. Their study shows that when women publish their research in journals with high-impact factors, they receive fewer citations from the engineering community.<ref name=":0" /> The authors explain their findings as a possible consequence of the "[[Matilda effect]]", a phenomenon that systematically undervalues the scientific contributions of women.
In addition to engineering, a gender bias in publishing is exemplified in economics. In 2015, Heather Sarsons released a working paper comparing credit allocated to men and women in collaborative research.<ref name=":1" /> Sarsons analyzed the publication records of economists at top universities over the past 40 years, and found that female economists publish work as frequently as their male cohorts, yet their tenure prospects are less than half that of men. Women receive comparable credit to men when they solo author their work or co-author with other female economist, evinced by a 8–9% increase in their tenure prospects, implying that tenure prospects decrease with collaborative work due to lack of credit given to women, not the quality of their work. Men receive the same amount of credit for solo authoring and co-authoring their work, shown by a 8–9% increase in their tenure prospects; however, when women co-author with men, there is no increase in their tenure prospects.
In the academic disciplines of political science and [[international relations]], research has found evidence of gender bias in publishing and teaching. The Teaching, Research and International Policy (TRIP) project gathers data and publishes analysis on the discipline of international relations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://trip.wm.edu/|title=Home {{!}} Teaching, Research, and International Policy (TRIP)|website=trip.wm.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref> In 2013, a study published by Daniel Maliniak, Ryan Powers and [[Barbara F. Walter]] used TRIP data from peer-reviewed publications between 1980 and 2006 to show that women are systematically cited less than men after controlling for a number of variables including year and venue of publication, substantive focus, theoretical perspective, methodology, tenure status, and institutional affiliation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maliniak|first=Daniel|last2=Powers|first2=Ryan|last3=Walter|first3=Barbara F.|date=2013/10|title=The Gender Citation Gap in International Relations|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/international-organization/article/gender-citation-gap-in-international-relations/3A769C5CFA7E24C32641CDB2FD03126A|journal=International Organization|language=en|volume=67|issue=4|pages=889–922|doi=10.1017/S0020818313000209|issn=0020-8183}}</ref> In a 2017 study on publishing patterns in political science journals, Dawn Langan Teele and [[Kathleen Thelen]] found that women authors are underrepresented compared to the share of women working in the profession, are not benefiting from the trend toward co-authored publications (dominated by all-male author teams), and lose out from the methodological partiality of top journals in the field.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teele|first=Dawn Langan|last2=Thelen|first2=Kathleen|date=2017/04|title=Gender in the Journals: Publication Patterns in Political Science|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/ps-political-science-and-politics/article/gender-in-the-journals-publication-patterns-in-political-science/07452099DCDCBF378D233FF402C97DEA|journal=PS: Political Science & Politics|language=en|volume=50|issue=2|pages=433–447|doi=10.1017/S1049096516002985|issn=1049-0965}}</ref> Activism aimed at uprooting gender bias in academic publishing and teaching has increased over the years and has led to initiatives such as #womenalsoknowstuff<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://womenalsoknowstuff.com/|title=Women Also Know Stuff|website=womenalsoknowstuff.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref>, #womenalsoknowhistory<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://womenalsoknowhistory.com/|title=Women Also Know History|work=Women Also Know History|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref>, and Jane Lawrence Sumner's Gender Balance Assessment Tool (GBAT)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jlsumner.shinyapps.io/syllabustool/|title=Gender Balance Assessment Tool (GBAT)|website=jlsumner.shinyapps.io|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref>. In 2015, Jeff Colgan conducted an analysis of American post-graduate international relations syllabi and found that 82% of assigned reading was written by all-male authors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://duckofminerva.com/2015/08/new-evidence-on-gender-bias-in-ir-syllabi.html|title=New Evidence on Gender Bias in IR Syllabi {{!}} Duck of Minerva|website=duckofminerva.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref> At the [[London School of Economics]], a student-led body called the Gender and Diversity Project (GDP) conducted a similar assessment of syllabi from the full teaching curriculum in the International Relations department from 2015 to 2016. The results, published in 2018 (see Kiran Phull, Gokhan Ciflikli and Gustav Meibauer<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Phull|first=Kiran|last2=Ciflikli|first2=Gokhan|last3=Meibauer|first3=Gustav|date=2018-08-20|title=Gender and bias in the International Relations curriculum: Insights from reading lists|journal=European Journal of International Relations|language=en|pages=135406611879169|doi=10.1177/1354066118791690|issn=1354-0661}}</ref>), revealed that 79.2% of assigned reading from all undergraduate, graduate, and post-graduate syllabi was authored exclusively by male authors, with the undergraduate curriculum being the least gender-diverse.
==See also== * [[Gender inequality]] * [[Gender pay gap]] * [[Gender role]] * [[Glass ceiling]] * [[Old boy network]], or male [[cronyism]] * [[Publish or perish]] * [[Sex discrimination in education]] * [[Sexism]] * [[Sexism in medicine]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last=Patton|first=Tracey|title=Reflections of a Black Woman Professor: Racism and Sexism in Academia|journal=Howard Journal of Communications|date=2004|volume=15|issue=3|pages=185–203|doi=10.1080/10646170490483629}} *[http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA320973511&v=2.1&u=mcc_gateway&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w&asid=11c1942565721dc32cbe5916ca8dab5f "Gender bias alive and well in academia."] ''Practical Neurology'' Feb. 2013: 66. Academic OneFile. Web. 10 May 2014. *{{cite thesis |last=Ratliff |first=Jacklyn M |title=A chilly conference climate: The influence of sexist conference climate perceptions on women's academic career intentions |type=Ph.D. |url=http://hdl.handle.net/1808/10328 |date=31 May 2012 |publisher=University of Kansas |accessdate=20 November 2013}}
==External links== *[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v387/n6631/abs/387341a0.html "Nepotism and sexism in peer-review"] ''at [[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' (journal)
[[Category:Higher education]] [[Category:Sexism|academia]] [[Category:Criticism of academia]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Shnaim Ohazin ('Two people holding') | image = Shaniam Ohazin Logo.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Shaniam Ohazin [[logo]]. | creator = | director = Arie Ben Tsion | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = Baruch Bar: [[Itsik Sayidoff]], Ori Orian: [[Avi Oriah]] | voices = | country = [[Israel]] | language = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 13 | producer = | editor = | location = | runtime = 24 minutes per episode | network = [[Israeli Educational Television]] | first_aired = | last_aired = }} '''''Shnaim Ohazin''''' ({{lang-he|שניים אוחזין}}, lit. ''Two people holding''), was a [[television show]] broadcast on the [[Israeli Educational Television]] during the 1980s that dealt with teaching basic concepts of the [[Talmud]] and Jewish heritage. The concept of the show was Mr. Bar and Mr. Orian meet to study [[Gemara]] (Talmud) together. The show was incorporated in the past as part of the 7th-grade curriculum in [[secondary school|secondary]] [[yeshiva]]s, or 9th-grade curriculum in secular Hebrew-speaking schools, and a study booklet was added in 1989, written and edited by Benjamin Domovitz. == Structure == The show had two hosts, Baruch Bar (The tall one — [[Itzik Sayedoff]]) and Ori Orian (The chubby one — [[Avi Oriah]]), who used a study room that has been converted to a television studio where they learn different topics in the Talmud while focusing on explaining basic concepts. The hosts are aware of the cameras and audience. After explaining the topic from the writings the two argue among themselves over the explanation of the subject. Then in a fictionalized segment they go back in time to the period of the [[Mishnah]] (around 200 CE) and discuss the topic of the day with ordinary people from the era, to try to learn which of their interpretations is correct. Almost all the chapters addressed interpretation and clarification of basic Talmud concepts.Except for chapter 9: "Who is afraid of Aramaic" which dealt with learning [[Aramaic language]]. == The meaning of "Shnaim Ohazin" == [[Image:Shaniam Ohazin-1.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Baruch Bar and Ori Oriah at their study tables.]] The name of the show is ''Shnaim Ohazin'' (Two who are holding) with a double meaning: The show speaks of studying the Talmud, and "[[Shnaim Ohazin (Talmud)|Shnaim Ohazin]]" is one of the famous Talmud chapters dealing with a division Principle,[[Seder Nezikin]], [[Bava Metzia]] [[Tract (literature)|tract]], First chapter. and also the name suggests that there are two teachers holding the [[Gemara]] and are learning and teaching it. The point of this is explained by Dr. [[Yehuda Schwartz]]:
"The Talmudic study is active with negotiating in a "[[Havruta]]" while viewing is passive. The study of the Talmud is mostly textual, while the television medium is not characterized by book and words. On top of that, study of the Talmud involves continual negotiation between the study partners, and this is difficult to present by television. The solution to these problems is found in the broadcast through creation of a dialogue between two participants: "Bar" and "Orian". The broadcast does not come in order to replace the study of Talmud but it is used as a helping instrument along with a guide to the teacher and paper assignments for the student."Doctorate on [http://www.daat.ac.il/daat/toshba/horaat/b6-2.htm Oral Torah] part two chapter c, Yehuda Schwartz (daat.ac.il)
The names of the teachers on the show also hold a [[symbol]]ic meaning: the names of both teachers Baruch Bar and Ori Orian ({{lang-he|'''ב'''רוך '''ב'''ר ו'''א'''ורי '''א'''וריין}}) are an [[alliteration]], their last names put together composes the term "Bar Orian" (Son/Student of the Torah in Aramaic, or "scholar" in [[Modern Hebrew]]). The name of Bar and Orian's teacher also suggests of his role: Shlomo '''Melamed''' ({{lang-he|מלמד}}, Teaches). == Cast == Director: * Arie Ben Tsion Actors: * Baruch Bar: [[Itsik Sayidoff]] * Ori Orian: [[Avi Oriah]] * Shlomo Melamed (Teacher of Bar and Orian): [[Shmuel Segal|Shmulik (Shmuel) Segal]] Guest actors: * [[Gabi Amrani]] * [[Eli Gorenstein]] * [[Michal Jacob]] * [[Armando Bismont]] * [[Eitan Ben-Dov]] * [[Dudik Smadar]] * [[Ariel Fridan]] * [[Gilad Baum]] == Chapters == # Ha Minei # Problem - Part A # Problem - Part B # Heicah Dami - Part A # Heicah Dami - Part B # Verminehu - Part A # Verminehu - Part B # Mai Tama # Who is afraid of Aramaic # Pshita - Part A # Pshita - Part B # Mena Hani Milei # Preciseness == See also == * [[Oral Torah]] * [[Hillel and Shammai]] == Notes == {{reflist}} === Bibliography === * Benjamin Domovitz, '''Shnaim Ohazin - Teacher's guide''', Ministry of Education Tel Aviv 5749 (1988-1989). * Benjamin Domovitz, '''Article "Shnaim Ohazin - Television series for teaching of terms, concepts and issues of the Talmud"''', "[[Shmaatin]]" magazine 5750 (1989-1990), Issue 99 pgs. 40-46. == External links == * [http://www.23tv.co.il/328-he/Tachi.aspx Shnaim Ohazin], on [[Israeli Educational Television]]. * [http://www.nrg.co.il/online/11/ART1/664/403.html 'Law and Order' by Einat Brazilai], [[NRG (Maariv)]] (Article about the show) [[Category:Education in Israel]] [[Category:Israeli television shows]] [[Category:IETV]] [[Category:1984 Israeli television series debuts]] [[Category:1985 Israeli television series endings]]

{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=July 2014}} {{cleanup-reorganize|date=July 2014}} }} {{Infobox organization |name =Telkom Foundation |image =Telkom_Foundation_Logo.jpg |imagesize =200px |country =[[Indonesia]] }} '''Telkom Foundation''' was formerly known as Telkom Education Foundation (YPT)[http://ypt.or.id/], YPT (Telkom Education Foundation) and Sandhykara Putra Telkom Foundation (YSPT). YPT has been providing service for 24 years while YSPT has also providing service for 34 years before both foundations merged in 2014. Now, under the name Telkom Foundation, the foundation has evolved into one of the best foundations in [[Indonesia]], in providing education services.
Introducing the One Pipe Education System (OPES) for primary & secondary level of educations, Telkom Foundation currently manages 44 schools. The schools manages certain levels of schools, including [[Kindergarten]], [[Primary school|Elementary]], [[Middle school|Junior]], [[High school|Senior high]], and Vocational School. Telkom Fondation also manages four higher education Institutions, [[Telkom University]], Telkom College of Telematics Technology (ST4), Sandhy Putra Tourism Academy Bandung & Telkom Academy Jakarta. Moreover, Telkom Foundation also manages Telkom Professional Development Center (Telkom PDC),[http://www.telkompdc.com/], Telkom PDC a training center dedicated in developing Indonesian Human Resource Competences.
Realizing the great size of financial power requires in developing education quality, in lines with attempt to complying World Class University level in 2017, Telkom Foundation has established several alternative funding sources; as up until now, Telkom Foundation developed four holding companies, which consist of PT. Edu Jasa Utama (PT. Mega Utama Rekanindo, PT. Mitra Karya Soludindo Utama, PT. Trengginas Jaya), PT. Jaringan Solusi Utama (PT. Sandhy Putra Makmur), PT Citra Sukapura Megah, and PT. Edu Medika Komunika ( PT. Radio Lintas Kontinental, PT. Radio Karang Tumaritis, PT. Tuvendo Jaya Utama, PT. Mekka, PT. Publika Edu Media), as well as Telkom Professional Certification Center, and Bandung Techno Park.{{cite web |url=http://ypt.or.id/new/bandung-techno-park/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713000647/http://ypt.or.id/new/bandung-techno-park/ |archivedate=2014-07-13 |df= }}, Bandung Techno Park
In 2017, Telkom Foundation Projecting its business units to achieve targeted revenue of 4 trillion IDR to support 80% operational cost of Telkom Foundation as it has committed to provide affordable qualified education for everyone. ==Historical of Telkom Foundation== ===YPT=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !History activity |- ||1989||Establishment of MBA Bandung |- ||1990||Establishment of YPT & STT Telkom |- ||1993||MBA Transformation of into STMB |- ||1996||Telkom Grant for K-lite Radio |- ||2000||Construction of STMB Campus |- ||2003||Procurement of Zora Radio, also establishing CDC and NTC |- ||2005||Construction of Cacuk Sudaryanto Building |- ||2007||Establishment of Telkom Polytechnic & Transformation from “Academy” to “institute” (Telkom Institute of Technology, Telkom Institute of Management) |- ||2008||Construction of Lab, Learning Center, and other Learning facilities |- ||2009||Transformation of IM Telkom Campus to be Integrated Campus |- ||2010||STISI Merged under the administration of YPT, thus Changed into STISI Telkom |- ||2011–2014||ISO 9001-2008 Certification, Lecture Development, Research, and Education as preparation toward World Class University |- ||2014||Organization Transforming |} ===YSPT=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !History activity |- ||1977||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Buah Batu, Kindergarten, Dayeuhkolot, Rancaekek |- ||1979||Division of Periska Postel Schools management; 4 Kindergartens asset handling of Perum Pos Giro tp Dharma Wanita. 9 Kindergartens and 2 elementary schools of PERUMTEL handed to the Dharma Wanita Housing Perum Telekomunikasi, establishment of PancarAtmaja Junior High ( which will be Telkom Junior High School Bandung ) |- ||1980||Establishment of YSPT, Pancar Atmaja Junior High School changed to Periska Postel Junior High School |- ||1981||Name alteration from Periska Postel Schools into Sandhy Putra, The formation of YSPT representative, and establishment of Sandhy Putra Cibeureum Kindergarten |- ||1983||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Singaraja Kindergarten, alteration of Periska Postel Junior High School to Sandhy Putra Junior High School |- ||1984||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Jambi Kindergarten |- ||1985||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Magelang Kindergarten |- ||1986||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Medan, Bogor, Pasuruan, and Ende Kindergarten |- ||1987||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Pekanbaru, Palembang I, Palembang II Kindergarten |- ||1988||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Pamatang Siantar, Bandar Lampung, and Solo Kindergarten |- ||1991||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Gorontalo & Sumbawa, and Sandhy Putra Makassar Tourism Vocational School |- ||1992||Establishment of Telkom Sandhy Putra Medan Vocational School, and Telkom Jakarta Vocational School, Medan Tourism Vocatinal School, Telkom Bandung Vocatioanal School. |- ||1993||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Tanjung Pinang Makassar Kindergarten |- ||1994||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Tourism Academy Bandung |- ||1995||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Benhkulu, Balikpapan Kindergarten |- ||1996||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Baturaja Kindergarten |- ||1998||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Jayapura Kindergarten, Sandhy Putra Banjarbaru Vocatioanal School |- ||1999||Establishment of Telkom Malang Vocational School & Sandhy Putra Banjarbaru Vocational School |- ||2000||Establishment of Telkom Purwekerto Vocational School |- ||2001||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Tarakan Play Group |- ||2002||Establishment of Sandhy Putra Batam Elementary School |- ||2002||Establishment of Telkom Sandhy Foundation=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !History activity |- ||2013||Merger of YPT-YSPT in one management |- ||2014||Transformation of primary and middle level education, the development of 4 faculties into 7 faculties at “[[Telkom University]]”. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Education in Indonesia]] [[Category:Foundations based in Indonesia]]

'''The Kennedy Airlift''' occurred in 1959 and 1960 and saw hundreds of east Africans get scholarships to study in the US. It was arranged by [[Tom Mboya]] and Senator [[John F. Kennedy]].<ref name= jfk>{{cite web| url = https://www.jfklibrary.org/JFK/JFK-in-History/JFK-and-the-Student-Airlift.aspx| title = JFK and the Student Airlift| publisher = [[John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum]]| access-date = 27 October 2016}}</ref>
==Background== The program began in earnest in 1959 when Mboya embarked on a speaking tour of the United States seeking scholarships for students from East Africa. The first batch of students, 81 in total, touched down on New York City in September 11 1959. These students would be settled in various universities in the United States and Canada. In Kenya, Mboya liaised with Julius Kiano and Kariuki Njiiri to identify potential students for the airlifts. Kiano and Njiiri were both alumni of American universities <ref>http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/magazine/Airlifts-to-the-US-The-first-Kenyans-to-study-in-America/434746-3472918-8ak1w4/index.html</ref>
The airlifts were opposed by Britain. Kenya was Britain's colony and Britain did not want America meddling with any of its colonies. British officials spread propaganda amongst top Kenyan students that American education was inferior to British education.
==Legacy== The airlifts officially ended in 1963. Most of the graduates from American and Canadian colleges and universities went back to help build the newly independent Kenya. Some were employed even before they graduated. They were mainly employed in the public administration sector as district and provincial officers. While men found it easy to get jobs they qualified for, women faced a tougher challenge. Many were offered secretarial duties despite being better qualified than most male officers in the same departments.
==Notable Beneficiaries== Over 800 students, mainly from Kenya, benefited from the Kennedy Airlift. Some of the more notable ones include:
[[Pamela Mboya|Pamela Odede Mboya]]
[[Wangari Maathai]]
[[Reuben_Olembo|Prof Reuben Olembo]]
Perez Olindo
Phillip Ochieng
Owino Okongo
==Barack Obama Snr== Contrary to some media reports, Barack Obama Snr, Barack Obama's father, was not a beneficiary of the airlifts. <ref>https://www.thenation.com/article/african-airlift/</ref> He received private funding to attend the University of Hawaii. He is, however, considered part of the 'airlift generation'.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{John F. Kennedy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kennedy Airlifts}} [[Category:Scholarships in the United States]] [[Category:1959 in Kenya]] [[Category:1960 in Kenya]]
