{{Infobox organization | name = The Trust for Public Land | image = | image_size = | alt = Logo for The Trust for Public Land | caption = | leader_title = President and Chief Executive Officer | leader_name = Diane Regas | logo = | | logo_size = 90px | logo_alt = | logo_caption = Logo for The Trust for Public Land (TPL) | abbreviation = | motto = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|1972}} | founder = [[Huey Johnson]] | founding_location = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], US | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = San Francisco, California, US | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | website = {{URL|www.tpl.org}} }} '''The Trust for Public Land''' is a U.S. [[nonprofit organization]] with a mission to "create parks and protect land for people, ensuring healthy, livable communities for generations to come."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/about|title=About us|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-22|language=en}}</ref> Since its founding in 1972, The Trust for Public Land has completed 5,000 park-creation and land conservation projects across the United States, protected over 3 million acres,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/our-work|title=I'm for parks and open space.|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> and helped pass more than 500 ballot measures--creating $70 billion in voter-approved public funding for parks and open spaces.<ref name="Fund">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/fund|title=Fund|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> The Trust for Public Land also researches and publishes authoritative data about parks, open space, conservation finance, and urban [[climate change adaptation]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> Headquartered in [[San Francisco]], the organization is among the largest U.S. conservation nonprofits,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2011/14/200-largest-us-charities-11_rank-environment-animal.html|title=The 200 Largest U.S. Charities List: Environment/Animal - Forbes|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en}}</ref> with approximately 30 field offices across the U.S., including a federal affairs function in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/offices|title=Offices|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/policy-legislation|title=Policy & Legislation|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/plan|title=Plan|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref>
== Focus Areas ==
Consistent with its "Land for People" mission, The Trust for Public Land is widely known for urban conservation work, including New York City playgrounds and community gardens,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/25/nyregion/a-new-playground-in-the-bronx-soaks-up-the-citys-problematic-storm-water.html|title=A New Playground in the Bronx Soaks Up the City’s Problematic Storm Water|last=Foderaro|first=Lisa W.|date=2015-06-24|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nycgovparks.org/about/history/community-gardens/movement|title=History of the Community Garden Movement : NYC Parks|website=www.nycgovparks.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref> Chicago's [[Bloomingdale Line|606]] linear park,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-606-trail-anniversary-met-0531-20160602-story.html|title=The 606 trail, a study in contrasts, celebrates its first birthday|last=Vivanco|first=Leonor|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Los Angeles green alleys,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/12/science/climate-change-alley-ways-water.html|title=Los Angeles Looks for Extra Water Down Its Alleys|last=Schlossberg|first=Tatiana|date=2016-07-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-20|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lastormwater.org/green-la/south-la-green-alley-master-plan/|title=South LA Green Alley Master Plan « City of Los Angeles Stormwater Program|work=City of Los Angeles Stormwater Program|access-date=2018-04-20|language=en-US}}</ref> Climate-Smart Cities programs in 20 American cities,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/climate-smart-cities#sm.0000f0sjbvumjfb9zva1tpr3x2n9a|title=Climate-Smart Cities™|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en}}</ref> and "The 10-Minute Walk" initiative, which aims to put a high-quality park or open space within a 10-minute walk of every resident of every U.S. urban census tract.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/10minutewalk|title=Everyone deserves a park|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-05-10|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.governing.com/gov-institute/voices/col-urban-parks-10-minute-challenge.html|title=Urban Parks and the 10-Minute Challenge|website=www.governing.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>
The Trust for Public Land simultaneously focuses on public access-oriented land protection, such as additions to [[Yosemite National Park]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/09/08/493081963/yosemite-national-park-grows-toward-west-in-largest-expansion-since-1949|title=Yosemite National Park Grows Toward West In Largest Expansion Since 1949|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> the [[Appalachian Trail]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedartmouth.com/article/2017/04/college-sells-farm-to-be-added-to-the-appalachian-trail|title=College sells farm to be added to the Appalachian Trail|work=The Dartmouth|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> [[Cape Cod National Seashore]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wgbh.org/wcai/ccns4.cfm|title=WCAI {{!}} Cape Cod National Seashore Anniversary|website=www.wgbh.org|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> and other national, state, and municipal parks across America.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303612804577533912723969448|title=Land Rush at National Parks|last=Carlton|first=Jim|date=2012-07-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-04-27|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/miles-of-california-coastline-to-be-preserved/2012/04/14/gIQApsfHIT_story.html|title=Miles of California coastline to be preserved|last=Barboza|first=Tony|date=2012-04-14|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-27|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncparks.gov/lumber-river-state-park-expands-1054-acres-trust-public-land-help|title=Lumber River State Park expands by 1,054 acres with Trust for Public Land help {{!}} NC State Parks|website=www.ncparks.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> The organization also prioritizes projects that celebrate and advance [[social equity]], like helping to create [[Martin Luther King Jr. National Historical Park]], the [[Stonewall National Monument]], and the [[Kashia Band of Pomo Indians of the Stewarts Point Rancheria|Kashia]] Coastal Reserve.<ref>{{Citation|title=Ownership of Tribal Land Restored at the Kashia Coastal Reserve|url=https://www.kcet.org/shows/california-coastal-trail/ownership-of-tribal-land-restored-at-the-kashia-coastal-reserve|language=en|accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref>
Although The Trust for Public Land is an accredited [[land trust]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.landtrustalliance.org/39-land-trusts-achieve-national-recognition|title=39 Land Trusts Achieve National Recognition|last=skatz|date=2017-08-10|website=www.landtrustalliance.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> the organization differs from conventional land trusts in that it does not generally hold or steward conservation property interests. Instead, The Trust for Public Land works with community members, public agencies, and other conservation [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] to identify park-creation and land protection projects, and then helps plan, fund, protect, and/or create those spaces, with ownership of any resulting property interests typically transferring to locale, state, or federal public agencies, or to other conservation NGOs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/frequently-asked-questions-0|title=Frequently Asked Questions|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref>
In addition to creating parks and protecting open spaces, The Trust for Public Land is a leading advocate for public conservation funding at the local, state, and federal levels.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/policy-legislation|title=Policy & Legislation|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/fund|title=Fund|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.outsideonline.com/2144781/6-best-environmental-groups-donate-better-world|title=The 6 Best Environmental Groups to Donate to for a Better World|last=Callaghan|first=Anna|date=2016-12-28|work=Outside Online|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en}}</ref> Through campaigns, ballot measures, and legislative advocacy, the organization works—often in concert with its affiliated [[501(c)4]] nonprofit, The Trust for Public Land Action Fund—to ensure adequate funding for many of the federal and state public funding programs relied on by public park and conservation agencies, and by conservation NGOs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tplactionfund.org/what-we-do/our-strategy/|title=Strategy - The Trust for Public Land Action Fund|work=The Trust for Public Land Action Fund|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/lwcf|title=LWCF: four letters you should know|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en}}</ref>
The Trust for Public Land also researches, publishes, and contributes to many authoritative national databases and platforms providing information about U.S. parks, protected open spaces, conservation finance, and urban climate risks, including [[ParkScore]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nextcity.org/daily/entry/parkscore-2017-park-systems-ranked|title=Ranked: Best and Worst of U.S. Park Systems|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> [[ParkServe]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://statescoop.com/about|title=About / Contact Us|website=StateScoop|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> [[Parkology]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/media-room/trust-public-land-makes-park-information-database-and-platform-available-millions|title=The Trust for Public Land Makes Park Information Database and Platform Available to Millions|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-19|language=en}}</ref> [[The Conservation Alamanac]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.conservationalmanac.org/secure/about.php|title=Conservation Almanac|website=www.conservationalmanac.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> the [[National Conservation Easement Database]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevenabernathy/2016/11/18/conserving-land-and-preserving-your-legacy-when-a-conservation-easement-should-be-considered/#742df08552ca|title=Conserving Land And Preserving Your Legacy: When A Conservation Easement Should Be Considered|last=Abernathy|first=Steven|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> [[LandVote]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/conservation-tools|title=Conservation tools|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en}}</ref> and "Climate-Smart Cities" [https://web.tplgis.org/csc-project-gallery/ Decision Support Tools].<ref name=":3" />
== Strategies, Programs and Initiatives ==
* ''Parks for People,'' a strategy for providing close-to-home access to nature through [[park]]s, [[playground]]s, [[trail]]s, [[community gardens]], and other outdoor public spaces in U.S. cities, towns, and [[suburb]]s<ref>{{cite web| first= Dashiell |last= Young-Saver|title=Through 'lost lots,' an effort to make L.A. more of a park place|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/cityhall/la-me-small-parks-20140823-story.html#page=1 |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=31 May 2015|date=August 22, 2014}}</ref> * ''Our Land,'' a strategy for protecting wild, working, and other open spaces, with an emphasis on enabling public access to natural areas for outdoor recreation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/ourland|title=#OurLand|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> * ''Climate-Smart Cities''™ program, which helps municipalities assess climate risks, develop resilience strategies, and identify sites for parks, greenways, and other multi-benefit green infrastructure, using [[GIS]]-based, city-specific [https://web.tplgis.org/csc-project-gallery/ decision support tools]<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/node/79108|title=Climate-Smart Cities™|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> * ''10-Minute Walk'' campaign—a collaboration with the [[National Recreation and Park Association]] and [[Urban Land Institute]]—which seeks to ensure that everyone in urban America lives within a 10-minute walk of a high-quality park or open space.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nrpa.org/parks-recreation-magazine/2017/december/the-10-minute-walk-campaign/|title=The 10-Minute Walk Campaign {{!}} Feature {{!}} National Recreation and Park Association|website=www.nrpa.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> Since this initiative's 2017 launch, 200 U.S. mayors have taken the 10-Minute Walk Pledge for their cities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/minneapolis-st-paul-mayors-join-national-push-for-parks-within-10-minute-walk/450317543/|title=Minneapolis, St. Paul mayors join national push for parks within 10-minute walk|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.10minutewalk.org/#Mayors|title=10 Minute walk|website=www.10minutewalk.org|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2018/04/26/1488530/0/en/NRPA-Awards-Grant-Funding-to-Support-Cities-Participating-in-10-Minute-Walk-Campaign.html|title=NRPA Awards Grant Funding to Support Cities Participating in 10-Minute Walk Campaign|last=Association|first=National Recreation and Park|work=GlobeNewswire News Room|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}}</ref> * ''Center for City Park Excellenc''e, which provides "research on parks and works to create, improve, and promote urban parks," and maintains The Trust for Public Land's [[ParkServe]], [[ParkScore]], and [[Parkology]] platforms, which provide, respectively, maps and data about 14,000 U.S. municipal park systems,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/media-room/parkserve-unveiled|title=ParkServe Database and Interactive Mapping Website Unveiled by The Trust for Public Land|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-05-02|language=en}}</ref> park system rankings for America's 100 largest cities,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/center-city-park-excellence|title=Center for City Park Excellence|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> and information about how communities can create and steward high-quality parks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.parkology.org/ParkShowPages?id=a1646000000dh2MAAQ|title=Parkology|last=|first=|date=|website=Parkology|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 May 2018}}</ref>
== Services ==
* ''Plan'' – The Trust for Public Land provides [[GIS]]-based spatial analysis services, including [[greenprinting]], greenway and trail planning, and large landscape analysis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesledger.com/stories/2017/21/ps120_2017_05_26_q.html|title=Work begins on PS 120’s new playground|work=TimesLedger|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.directionsmag.com/article/7243|title=GeoInspirations: Breece Robertson - Making a Positive Difference on Protected Lands|website=www.directionsmag.com|access-date=2018-04-23}}</ref> * ''Fund'' – The organization advocates for public conservation funding by providing technical assistance, campaign services, research data, and conservation economics analyses.<ref name="Fund"/> * ''Protect'' – The Trust for Public Land works with willing sellers, public agencies, and conservation nonprofits to negotiate, structure, fund, and complete the conservation real estate transactions that result in the acquisition and protection of land for parks and open spaces.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/how-we-work/protect|title=Protect|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref> * ''Create'' – The organization helps communities plan, site, design, construct, and restore parks, using [[community engagement]], [[Participatory design|participatory design,]] and [[creative placemaking]] techniques.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tpl.org/node/79114/|title=Create|work=The Trust for Public Land|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en}}</ref>
== History ==
The Trust for Public Land was founded in San Francisco in 1972 by [[Huey Johnson]], the former western regional director of [[The Nature Conservancy]], and other San Francisco Bay Area and national lawyers and conservationists. Johnson’s goal was to create an organization that would use emerging real estate, legal, and financial techniques to conserve land for human use and public benefit. An additional founding goal was to extend the conservation and environmental movements to cities, where an increasingly large segment of the population lived.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt1199n4bs&brand=oac4&doc.view=entire_text|title=Trust for Public Land Founding Member and President, 1972-1997: the Ethics and Practice of Land Conservation,|website=oac.cdlib.org|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> Early Trust for Public Land programs of the 1970s and ‘80s included:
* ''The Urban Land Program'', which led to the creation of parks and gardens in [[Oakland, California]], San Francisco, New York City, [[Newark, New Jersey]], and other cities.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt1199n4bs&brand=oac4&doc.view=entire_text|title=Trust for Public Land Founding Member and President, 1972-1997: the Ethics and Practice of Land Conservation |website=oac.cdlib.org|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> * ''The Public Land Program'', which included transactions that helped create the [[Golden Gate National Recreation Area]], [[Cuyahoga Valley National Park]], and the [[Sawtooth National Recreation Area]] in [[Idaho]], among other parks and preserves.<ref name=":0" /> * ''The Land Trust Program'', which helped found or train about one-third of the nation’s then-existing local [[land trust]]s. In the 1980s, the Trust for Public Land joined other groups to found the [[Land Trust Alliance]], in order to train and support local land trusts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.landtrustalliance.org/about/history|title=History|last=Administrator|date=2014-09-15|website=www.landtrustalliance.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref>
== The Trust for Public Land Action Fund == As a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, The Trust for Public Land is legally limited in the amount it can spend on campaigning for legislative and ballot measures. In 2000, the organization launched a 501(c)(4) affiliate, The Conservation Campaign, which is not limited in such spending. This affiliate entity is now called The Trust for Public Land Action Fund and frequently works with The Trust for Public Land to help pass local and state conservation finance measures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tplactionfund.org/|title=Home - The Trust for Public Land Action Fund|website=The Trust for Public Land Action Fund|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Tom Sleigh 2011.jpg|thumb|Tom Sleigh, 2011]]'''Tom Sleigh''' ({{IPAc-en|s|l|eɪ}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[poet]], [[dramatist]], [[essayist]] and [[academic]], who lives in [[New York City]]. He has published nine books of original poetry, one full-length translation of [[Euripides]]' ''[[Herakles (Euripides)|Herakles]]'' and two books of essays. His most recent books are House of Fact, House of Ruin: Poems and The Land Between Two Rivers: Writing In an Age of Refugees (essays). At least five of his plays have been produced. He has won numerous awards, including the 2008 [[Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award]], worth $100,000,[http://www.pshares.org/Authors/authorDetails.cfm?prmAuthorID=1425 Ploughshares, the literary journal] an Academy Award from the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]], The Shelley Award from the [[Poetry Society of America]], and a [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] grant. He currently serves as director of [[Hunter College]]'s [http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/creativewriting/ Master of Fine Arts (MFA) program in Creative Writing]. He is the recipient of the Anna-Maria Kellen Prize and Fellow at the [http://www.americanacademy.de/ American Academy in Berlin] for Fall 2011. ==Life== Tom Sleigh was born in [[Mount Pleasant, Texas]], where he lived until the age of five, when he moved to [[Utah]]. He lived in Utah until seventh grade, when he moved to [[California]].[http://www.bu.edu/agni/interviews/online/2003/sleigh-wong.html AGNI Online: Interview with Tom Sleigh by Allegra Wong] He attended the [[California Institute of the Arts]], [[Evergreen State College]], and the Writing Seminars [[Johns Hopkins University]][http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/2000/mar00/sleigh.html Dartmouth News - Dartmouth professor Thomas Sleigh nominated for L.A. Times book prize - 03/24/00] for two years, where he graduated with an MA. In his mid-twenties he moved to [[Massachusetts]], to work at the [[Fine Arts Work Center]] in [[Provincetown, Massachusetts|Provincetown]]. He began teaching at [[Dartmouth College]] in 1986 and later taught at [[New York University]], the [[University of Iowa]], [[UC-Berkeley]] and Johns Hopkins University. He lives in [[Brooklyn]], New York, and serves as director of the Hunter College Master of Fine Arts Program in Creative Writing, where he also teaches poetry writing. ==Artistic influences== In an interview published in the literary journal [[AGNI (magazine)|''AGNI'']], Sleigh lists his poetic influences:
I'd have to say that [[Robert Browning|Browning]] for his technique; [[Wallace Stevens]] for a certain quality of gravitas, what [[Keats]] feels near his death, when he said he was living a sort of posthumous existence; [[Philip Larkin]] for his sense of extremity; [[Ezra Pound|Pound]] for his fluidity of conception and hardness of execution; [[Baudelaire]] for his music and intense scrutiny and affection for street life; and [[Elizabeth Bishop|Bishop]] and [[Robert Lowell|Lowell]] for their immersion in the physical world, would be my fathers and mothers.
==Published works== ;Poetry collections * ''House of Fact, House of Ruin'' (Graywolf Press, 2017) * ''Station Zed'' (Graywolf Press, 2015) * ''Army Cats'' (Graywolf Press, 2011) * ''Space Walk'' (Houghton Mifflin Company, 2007) * ''Far Side of the Earth'' (Houghton Mifflin Company, 2003) * ''The Dreamhouse'' (University of Chicago Press, 1999) * ''The Chain'' (University of Chicago Press, 1996) * ''Waking'' (University of Chicago Press, 1990) * ''After One'' (Houghton Mifflin Company, 1983) ;Prose works * ''The Land Between Two Rivers: Writing in an Age of Refugees'' (Graywolf Press, 2017) * ''Interview with a Ghost'' ([[Graywolf Press]], 2006) ;Dramatic works * ''Ice Trucker Pilgrimage'', a multi-media opera (presented at San Francisco Film Festival 2006) * ''The Knowledge and Conversation of My Holy Guardian Angel, or an Old-Fashioned Love Story'' (produced in 2004, New York Fringe Theater Festival) * ''Rubber'' (performed at the Midtown International Theatre Festival, Raw Space Theater, New York City, 2002; winner of "Best of the Fest" award and a 2003 OOBR Award from the Off Off Broadway Review) * ''Barbarosa'' (staged reading at Boston University's Playwright's Theater, 1998) * ''Ahab's Wife'' (performed at Loeb's ART Institute, Boston, 1997; and Jim Henson Foundation's International Festival of Puppet Theater, New York City, 1998) ;Translations * ''Herakles'' by Euripides (Oxford University Press USA, 2000) ==Honors and awards== * Kingsley Tufts Award (2008), for ''Space Walk'' [http://www.pw.org/content/poet_tom_sleigh_walks_away_100000 Poet Tom Sleigh Walks Away With $100,000 | Poets & Writers] * Academy Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters * The Shelley Award from the Poetry Society of America * Guggenheim Foundation Grant * Ingram Merill Foundation Grant * Two National Endowment for the Arts grants ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * http://www.bu.edu/agni/interviews/online/2003/sleigh-wong.html * http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/2000/mar00/sleigh.html * http://www.pshares.org/authors/author-detail.cfm?authorID=1425 * http://www.pw.org/content/poet_tom_sleigh_walks_away_100000 ==External links== * http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/creativewriting/sleigh.shtml - Tom Sleigh's official website * http://www.slate.com/id/2120981/ - A recording of Sleigh reading his poem "The Hole" * http://www.slate.com/id/2175506 - A recording of Sleigh reading his poem "Recording" * http://www.bostonreview.net/BR21.5/sacks.html - A review of ''The Chain'' {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sleigh, Tom}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Writers from Texas]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University alumni]] {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=June 2016}} {{Notability|date=October 2018}} {{Unreferenced|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox university | name = Faculty of Science | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | motto_lang = | mottoeng = | established = <!-- {{Start date|df=yes|YYYY}} --> | closed = <!-- {{End date|df=yes|YYYY}} --> | type = [[State university|Public]]| | parent = [[University of Auckland]] | affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | dean = Professor [[Grant Guilford]] | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = > 7,000 | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | city = [[Auckland]] | country = [[New Zealand]] | coor = | campus = | language = | website = {{URL|www.science.auckland.ac.nz}} | logo = }}
The '''University of Auckland Faculty of Science''' is one of eight faculties and schools that make up the [[University of Auckland]].
== Divisions == *School of Biological Sciences *School of Chemical Sciences *Department of Computer Science *School of Environment *Institute of Marine Science *Department of Mathematics *Department of Physics *School of Psychology *Department of Exercise Sciences *Department of Statistics
== Science Programs == '''Undergraduate Programs''' *Bachelor of Science (BSc) *Graduate Diploma in Science (GradDipSci)
'''Conjoint Programs''' *Bachelor of Arts/Bachelor of Science - (BA/BSc) *Bachelor of Commerce/Bachelor of Science - (BCom/BSc) *Bachelor of Engineering(Hons)/Bachelor of Science - (BE(Hons)/BSc) *Bachelor of Science/Bachelor of Nursing - (BSc/BNurs) *Bachelor of Music/Bachelor of Science - (BMus/BSc) *Bachelor of Property/Bachelor of Science - (BProp/BSc) *Bachelor of Science/Bachelor of Laws - (BSc/LLB) *Bachelor of Science/Bachelor of Laws(Hons) - (BSc/LLB(Hons))
'''Postgraduate Programs''' *Honours **Bachelor of Science (Honours) *Postgraduate Certificate/Diploma **Postgraduate Certificate in Information Technology **Postgraduate Diploma in Science (PGDipSci) **Postgraduate Diploma in Applied Psychology (PGDipAppPsych) **Postgraduate Diploma in Bioscience Enterprise (PGDipBioEnt) **Postgraduate Diploma in Clinical Psychology (PGDipClinPsy) **Postgraduate Diploma in Forensic Science (PGDipForensic) **Postgraduate Diploma in Operations Research (PGDipOR) *Masters **Master of Information Technology **Master of Speech Language Therapy Practice (MSLTPrac) **Master of Professional Studies in Data Science (MProfStuds) **Master of Professional Studies in Digital Security (MProfStuds) **Master of Professional Studies in Food Safety (MProfStuds) **Master of Professional Studies in Mathematics Education (MProfStuds) **Master of Science (MSc) **Master of Bioscience Enterprise (MBioEnt) **Master of Operations Research(MOR)
'''Doctoral Programs''' *Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) *Doctor of Clinical Psychology (DClinPsy)
'''Other Programs''' *Graduate Certificate in Innovation and Entrepreneurship (GradCertInnovEnt) *Graduate Diploma in Innovation and Entrepreneurship (GradDipInnovEnt) *Postgraduate Certificate in Commercialisation and Entrepreneurship (PGCertCE) *Master of Energy (MEnergy) *Masters of Commercialisation and Entrepreneurship (MCE) *Certificate of Proficiency (COP)
==External links==
* [http://www.science.auckland.ac.nz Official website of the Faculty of Science, University of Auckland]
